title: How To Train Your Dog To Leave It
summary: There are several ways to make your dog more aware of what’s off limits. The “Leave It” command is simple enough that even young puppies can learn it and understand it. Reward and games are another excellent way to train your dog and get him used to being around your things without touching them. Remember that training your dog to leave things alone won’t happen overnight. Like humans, dogs also have to learn as they go, and they’re bound to make mistakes along the way.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Perhaps the most frustrating thing about owning a dog is that your house can never really be your own again. Fussing and fuming won\u2019t make them any less likely to follow you anywhere, or to notice that bag of chips you just carelessly threw on the table. Dogs are dogs, which means they will follow your slightest lead and chip in with their two cents at every opportunity. Sadly, this also means that it\u2019s not uncommon for dogs to get into things they shouldn\u2019t. You like peace and quiet? Not so much when there\u2019s a dog around. You like keeping your things? Good luck with that.
But luckily, with some bit of training and persistence, you can teach your pup exactly what\u2019s off limits and exactly where to leave it instead. Best of all, all these tricks take very little time and effort on our part. It doesn\u2019t have to be hard! Let\u2019s check out how!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Rule 1: Have A Dinner Party"),mdx("p",null,"Dogs love food, and if they\u2019ve learned that food is off limits, they\u2019re bound to get curious. Now, you don\u2019t want your dog to get sick, but you also don\u2019t want him to get into any trouble. There are several ways to make your dog more aware of what\u2019s off limits. One of the easiest is to invite a few friends over for a dinner party. Why? Because, at a dinner party, almost everything is off limits. You want to keep your dog away from the food and drinks, of course, but you also want to keep him away from the tablecloth, the flowers on the table, and any other potential trouble."),mdx("h2",null,"Rule 2: Use a \u201CLeave It\u201D Command"),mdx("p",null,"Another easy and effective way to train your dog is by introducing a \u201CLeave it\u201D command. How does it work? Well, every time your dog starts to get curious about something, you simply use this command. If your dog starts mouthing your couch, for example, you can use the command \u201CLeave it.\u201D If your dog starts digging in the dirt, you can use the same command. The \u201CLeave it\u201D command is simple enough that even young puppies can learn it and understand it! Once your dog knows the command and has started to get used to obeying it, you can also add a hand signal to make things even more clear."),mdx("h2",null,"Rule 3: Use Rewards And Games To Train Your Dog"),mdx("p",null,"Rewards and games are another excellent way to train your dog and get him used to being around your things without touching them. If your dog starts getting curious about something, try giving him a toy or a treat to get his mind off of it. If he starts to get too excited, clap your hands and tell him \u201CNo.\u201D You can even use the same toys to teach your dog that certain things are off limits. If, for example, your dog keeps getting excited about your old sneakers, put them in a toy. Your dog will have fun trying to get the shoes out, and he\u2019ll learn that they\u2019re not something he should be mouthing."),mdx("h2",null,"Rule 4: Teach Your Dog About Touching Things"),mdx("p",null,"Now, some things are just going to be off limits. For example, you don\u2019t want your dog to eat your birthday cake, no matter how much he might want to. You don\u2019t want him to get too close to the stove, either. But you don\u2019t want him to be afraid of his own birthday present, so you have to find a way to teach him about touching things. The first thing you should do is to make sure that your dog has plenty of space and something to chew on. Rawhides, for example, are great for dogs, and they\u2019re safe enough to leave around your house. If your dog has his own toys, he\u2019ll be less likely to go digging in your stuff. You can also try spraying things like the stove and the kitchen table with a water bottle. That\u2019ll let your dog know that it\u2019s not okay to come too close."),mdx("h2",null,"Rule 5: Be Patient & Stick With It"),mdx("p",null,"Finally, remember that training your dog to leave things alone won\u2019t happen overnight. Like humans, dogs also have to learn as they go, and they\u2019re bound to make mistakes along the way. That\u2019s not a bad thing, though. Mistakes are actually how dogs learn. If your dog makes a mistake, don\u2019t get mad. Instead, let him know that he did something wrong and try again. Let\u2019s say your dog is chewing on your couch, for example. Instead of getting mad, just get his attention and say \u201COff.\u201D And if he keeps chewing on the couch, try spraying it with water. If your dog doesn\u2019t learn to leave things alone, you might find yourself hating house parties and having to keep your things out of sight at all times. So, let your dog in on the fun by teaching him to leave things alone!"),mdx("h2",null,"Final Words"),mdx("p",null,"Thank you for reading, and we hope you found our article helpful! In order to train your dog to leave things alone, you have to be patient and consistent. It might take a while to get your dog to understand these rules, but you have to be patient and consistent and you will get there. We strongly encourage you to follow these tips and make sure you follow through with them. At the end of the day, training your dog to leave things alone is not only helpful for you, but also for your dog. By teaching your dog to leave certain things alone, you\u2019re also teaching him not to be rude and to respect your things."),mdx("p",null,"Now, your home can truly be your own again. Your dog can play and eat and dig, but he\u2019ll do it on his own terms. And you\u2019ll be able to enjoy your things without having to worry about your dog ruining them."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with Envy in Relationships

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Being in a new relationship is exciting and often feels like a whirlwind. You spend time getting to know each other and spending time together as much as possible. But things can change once you enter a committed relationship or get married. Stressors from work, family, friends and other responsibilities may arise, putting stress on your relationship. This is when green-eyed monster envy creeps in and can have a negative impact on your partner.
There are many different types of relationships: friendships, casual dating or serious partners. Regardless of what type of relationships you have with another person, envy probably won\u2019t be far behind if they are important to you. Envy is one of the seven deadly sins for good reason. When we experience envy in a relationship it creates distrust, resentment and can ultimately end things prematurely before they even really begin. However, there are ways to deal with this feeling so that it doesn\u2019t get the better of you.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Get over a Break-Up

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In the unfortunate event that you find yourself in a situation where you need to get over a break-up, it\u2019s important to know what to do in order to help the healing process along. Break-ups are never easy, and they can be even more difficult and hurtful if it\u2019s with your first love or someone you really cared about. These tips will help get you through any heartbreak and back into a place of peace.
When you experience a break-up, whether it\u2019s from a partner, friend or family member, it leaves you with an empty feeling. It hurts so much because you placed so many emotions into the relationship that it now feels like a part of who you are has been taken from you. Even though the person who broke up with you may have been oblivious to the pain they were causing by ending things, that doesn\u2019t make breaking up any easier for anyone involved.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: From First Date to Soulmate: How to Know If You're on the Right Track

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`There are so many first date horror stories out there \u2014 awkward silences, strange amateur- magician tricks, and cringe-worthy pick-up lines being just a few of them. But getting past these awkward initial stages and finding a potential partner who you can connect with on a deeper level is no mean feat. Figuring out if someone is your soulmate or simply the first step to becoming one isn\u2019t easy. Even though it can feel like we\u2019re constantly being bombarded with images of fairy tale love and meet-cute romances, dating in real life isn\u2019t always so straightforward. Unless you\u2019re living under a rock, you probably know that letting somebody into your private world isn\u2019t something to take lightly.
But how do you know if you\u2019re on the right track when it comes to dating? Whether you\u2019ve just met someone new and want to get to know them better without rushing things or have been seeing somebody for some time and are wondering if they could be The One, here are some signs that could indicate that this person may be more than just a casual partner\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Tips for Eating Healthy on a Budget

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you trying to eat healthier but find that healthy foods are expensive? Are you trying to make a good meal last for several days and not just one? Are you struggling to find affordable, healthy options near your home or work? If so, you\u2019re not alone. Eating healthy can be expensive and challenging. The cost of healthy food has gone up while the cost of unhealthy food has gone down. But this doesn\u2019t mean that eating healthy is impossible; it just means we all need to get a little bit more creative.
Eating well on a budget can be challenging, but it isn\u2019t impossible. Making smart choices about what you buy as well as how you cook your food can make a big difference in how much money you spend on food each month and how healthy your diet is at the same time.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Travelling
How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Working

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Working too much is a problem many people struggle with \u2014 but it\u2019s even more challenging when you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who has the same work ethic. If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Beat the Winter Blues

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The winter blues is a mood disorder that can affect anyone, not just people from northern regions. Symptoms of the winter blues are essentially SAD (seasonal affective disorder) brought on by the shorter days and colder temperatures of winter. If you find yourself feeling blue during the colder months but don\u2019t necessarily have a reason to be, you might have the winter blues. The good news is that you can combat this feeling with a little help from your friends and some lifestyle changes.
Whether you have or have had the winter blues in the past, there are ways to boost your spirits when those long, dreary days of January creep up on you like an old friend you don\u2019t want to see again. Here are some ways to beat those pesky winter blues and get back to your happy self!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How the Pandemic Is Changing the Way We Work

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...n}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...n,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Time is money, as the saying goes. And when you\u2019re grappling with pandemic disease and a global outbreak, time spent at work has a whole different set of implications.
Pandemic flu strains have decimated human populations since the first recorded pandemic in 541 AD. Over the centuries, outbreaks have been frequent enough to instill fear in even the most stoic among us.
Today we face another pandemic threat with the potential to be even more devastating than those which came before it. A highly virulent strain of influenza A virus known as influenza pandemia has begun spreading rapidly throughout much of the world.
In many ways, today\u2019s workplace is very different from that of a century ago. Technology has advanced; office structures are more open and collaborative; and workers are expected to demonstrate self-motivation and flexibility in order to thrive in an ever-changing workplace environment.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Sit
The Ultimate Guide to Spring Cleaning Your Home

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Home cleaning in spring is the best time to thoroughly clean your home. As the weather gets warmer, so does our house. Dirt and grime that has accumulated over the long winter months begins to dissipate as we put away all of our heavy coats, hats, and gloves. With fewer layers to trap it, dust, germs, and other nasty particles are exposed for what they really are: gross!
We all know that a tidy home is a happy one. Keeping a tidy household at all times can be challenging. The pressures of work and other responsibilities often get in the way of keeping things clean and organized. But with some preparation and planning you can make spring home cleaning your primary focus instead of an afterthought. Here\u2019s how\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
